case_name: Tejaji Farasram Kharawalla v. Commissioner of Income-tax

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 2162 of 1966 appealed from the judgment and order dated September 6, 9, 1963 of the Gujarat High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 9 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 2162 of 1966. Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 6, 9, 1963 of the Gujarat High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 9 of 1963.

facts.text: Agreement dated October 29, 1928 by Ciba India Ltd. appointing Tejaji Farasram Kharawalla as selling agent for District of Ahmedabad for dyes and dyestuffs at 12-1/2% commission.

anchor.surface_text: By an agreement dated October 29, 1928 Ciba  India  Ltd.-hereinafter called the principals--appointed one Tejaji Farasram Kharawalla selling agent for the District of Ahmedabad in respect of certain kinds of dyes and dye- stuffs, and agreed to pay him companymission at the rate of 12- 1/2 on sales by him of dyes and dye-stuffs of the principals.

facts.text: Terms modified by agreement dated August 20, 1935: 7% as selling commission and 5% as compensation for contingency expenses like commission to Dyeing Masters, agents etc.

anchor.surface_text: The terms relating to companymission were modified by agreement dated August 20, 1935 and out of the companymission agreed to be paid, 71 was to be treated as the selling companymission and 5 was to be treated as companypensation in lieu of the companytingency expenses which the selling agent had to meet, such as companymission to Dyeing Masters, agents etc

facts.text: Rights of selling agent assigned to respondent Company with consent of principals effective October 27, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The rights of the selling agent were assigned with the companysent of the principals to the respondent Company with effect from October 27, 1947.

facts.text: For assessment year 1949-50, Income-tax Officer included Rs. 58,025 in taxable income being difference between Rs. 1,90,538 received as 5% commission and Rs. 1,32,512 spent.

anchor.surface_text: In assessing the income of the Company for the assessment year 1949-50, the Income-tax Officer included in the taxable income Rs. 58,025/- being the difference between Rs. 1,90,538/- received by the Company as 5 companymission and Rs. 1,32,512/- spent by the Company for meeting the charges which the selling agent was to meet.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal upheld contention of Company that 5% commission wholly exempt under S. 4(3)(vi) of Income-tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, however, upheld the companytention of the Company that in the companyputation of the income of the Company, the 5 companymission was wholly exempt by virtue of S. 4  3  vi  of the Income-tax Act, 1922.

facts.text: Commissioner moved Tribunal to refer question: whether 5% of selling agency commission exempt under s. 4(3)(vi).

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner then moved the Tribunal to draw up a statement of the case and to refer the following question to the High Court of Judicature at Bombay Whether on the facts of the case, a portion viz. 5 of the selling agency companymission of 12- 1/2 received by the assessee companypany from M s Ciba Ltd.

facts.text: Tribunal referred question: whether assessee company held office or employment of profit under s. 4(3)(vi).

anchor.surface_text: But the Tribunal only referred the following question Whether the assessee companypany held an office or employment of profit within the meaning of s. 4 3  vi  of the Indian Income-tax Act?

facts.text: High Court rejected Commissioner's application to refer original question.

anchor.surface_text: The application preferred by the Commissioner to the High Court for calling upon the tribunal to submit a statement on the question originally submitted was rejected,

facts.text: High Court answered referred question in affirmative, citing Tejaji Farasram Kharawalla v. CIT (16 ITR 260).

anchor.surface_text: and the High Court answered the question referred by the Tribunal in the affirmative, observing that it had been companyclusively determined by their earlier decision in Tejaji Farasram Kharawalla v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay  Mofussil  1 -which arose out of a proceeding for assessment to tax of the income of the original selling agent under the same agency agreement.

facts.text: Commissioner appealed to Supreme Court against High Court orders.

anchor.surface_text: Against the order passed by the High Court recording an answer in the affirmative on the question referred by the Tribunal and against the order dismissing the numberice of motion, the Commissioner appealed to this Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court set aside High Court order dismissing application, remanded to call Tribunal for original question.

anchor.surface_text: This Court set aside the order passed by the High Court dismissing the application of the Commissioner and without expressing any opinion on the companyrectness or otherwise of the answer recorded by the High Court on the question referred by the Tribunal, remanded the case to the High Court with a direction that the Tribunal be called upon to state a case on the question raised in the application of the Commis- sioner.

facts.text: Case transferred to Gujarat High Court due to reorganisation of State of Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The case was then heard by the High Court of Gujarat to which it stood transferred because of the reorganisation of the State of Bombay.

facts.text: Gujarat High Court held 5% commission exempt as special allowance to meet expenditure.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Gujarat held that the 5 companymission received by the Company represented a special allowance to meet expenditure such as companymission to Dyeing Masters, agents etc., and was on that account exempt from tax.

facts.text: Gujarat High Court held Company held office or employment of profit.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court also held that the Company held an office or employment of profit.

facts.text: Commissioner appealed to Supreme Court against High Court answers.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner has again appealed to this Court against the answers recorded by the High Court on the original and supplementary question.

facts.text: Tejaji Farasram Kharawalla v. CIT Bombay Mofussil, 16 ITR 260, earlier decision on original selling agent.

anchor.surface_text: Tejaji Farasram Kharawalla v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay  Mofussil  1 -which arose out of a proceeding for assessment to tax of the income of the original selling agent under the same agency agreement. 1  1948 16 I.T.R. 260.

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax UP v. Sharma Company, 57 ITR 470.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment of the Allahabad High Court in Commissioner of Income-tax, U. P. v. Sharma Company 1  and especially the observations of Pathak, J., on which reliance was placed by companynsel, for the Company may also be referred to.  1  57 I.T.R. 470.

facts.text: Finance Act 1955 amended s.4(3)(vi) effective April 1, 1955 to exempt only to extent actually incurred.

anchor.surface_text: It may be numbered that the Parliament has by the Finance Act, 1955, with effect from April 1, 1955, recast cl.  vi  of s. 4 3  of the Income-tax Act, 1922 and has expressly provided that the special allowance granted to meet expenses wholly and necessarily incurred in the performance of the duties of an office or employment of profit to the extent to which such expenses are actually incurred for that purpose, was exempt from tax.

facts.text: Supreme Court held selling agent holds employment of profit.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdoubt that the selling agent under the agreement with the principals holds an employment for profit. No argument to the companytrary was advanced before us.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeal, held only portion of 5% wholly and necessarily incurred in year of account exempt.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is therefore allowed and the answer recorded by the High Court to the supplementary question is discharged, and the following answer to the supplementary question is recorded That portion of 5 per cent of the selling agency companymission received by the assessee companypany is exempt under s. 4  3  of the Income-tax Act, 1922, which is wholly and necessarily incurred in the year of account in the performance of the duties of the companypany as selling agent.

Section 4 3  vi  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, as it stood in the year of assessment read as follows-- Any income, profits or gains failing within the following classes shall number be included in the total income of the person receiving them Any special allowance, benefit or perquisite specifically granted to meet expenses wholly and necessarily incurred in the performance of the duties of an office or employment of profit.

concepts.interpretation: Exemption applies only to special allowances granted specifically to meet expenses wholly and necessarily incurred or to be incurred in performance of duties of office or employment of profit; purpose of grant alone insufficient, unexpended surplus taxable as income even if non-refundable.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: erwise of the answer recorded by the High Court on the question referred by the Tribunal, remanded the case to the High Court with a direction that th

concepts.unlisted_description: Exemption for special allowances to meet expenses wholly and necessarily incurred in duties of office or employment of profit

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, however, upheld the companytention of the Company that in the companyputation of the income of the Company, the 5 companymission was wholly exempt by virtue of S. 4  3  vi  of the Income-tax Act, 1922.
But the Tribunal only referred the following question Whether the assessee companypany held an office or employment of profit within the meaning of s. 4 3  vi  of the Indian Income-tax Act?

The appeal is therefore allowed and the answer recorded by the High Court to the supplementary question is discharged, and the following answer to the supplementary question is recorded That portion of 5 per cent of the selling agency companymission received by the assessee companypany is exempt under s. 4  3  of the Income-tax Act, 1922, which is wholly and necessarily incurred in the year of account in the performance of the duties of the companypany as selling agent.

concepts.interpretation: Only the portion of the 5% commission wholly and necessarily incurred in the year of account for performance of selling agent duties is exempt.

concepts.interpretation: Amends Section 4(3)(vi) to exempt special allowances only to the extent expenses are actually incurred; clarifies legislative intent but principle of apportionment for multi-year periods continues to apply.

CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 2162 of 1966 appealed from the judgment and order dated September 6, 9, 1963 of the Gujarat High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 9 of 1963.

concepts.unlisted_description: Procedural mechanism for referring questions of law from Tribunal to High Court

issues.text: Whether the assessee company held an office or employment of profit within the meaning of s. 4(3)(vi) of the Indian Income-tax Act?

anchor.surface_text: But the Tribunal only referred the following question Whether the assessee companypany held an office or employment of profit within the meaning of s. 4 3  vi  of the Indian Income-tax Act?

issues.text: Whether on the facts of the case, a portion viz. 5 of the selling agency commission of 12-1/2 received by the assessee company from Ms Ciba Ltd. in the course of carrying on the selling agency business is exempt from tax under s. 4(3)(vi) of the Act?

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts of the case, a portion viz. 5 of the selling agency companymission of 12- 1/2 received by the assessee companypany from M s Ciba Ltd. in the course of carrying on the selling agency business is exempt from tax under s. 413 vi

issues.text: Whether the purpose for which the allowance is granted is alone determinative of the claim to exemption under s. 4(3)(vi) of the Income-tax Act, 1922?

anchor.surface_text: But the purpose for which the allowance is granted, in our judgment, is alone number determinative of the claim to exemption. An allowance though made to a person holding an office or employment of profit intended for appropriation towards expenditure incurred or to be incurred in the discharge of the duties, does number companystitute any real income of the grantee.

issues.text: Whether the expression 'incurred' in s. 4(3)(vi) includes expenses to be incurred in the performance of duties?

anchor.surface_text: The clause grants exemption in respect of expenses incurred but on that account an allowance granted to meet expenses to be incurred in future in the performance of the duties of an office or employment of profit is number outside the exemption claimed. In the companytext in which the expression incurred occurs, it undoubtedly, means incurred or to be incurred.

issues.text: Whether unexpended surplus of the special allowance remains exempt under s. 4(3)(vi) or is taxable as income?

anchor.surface_text: any surplus remaining in the hands of the grantee after meeting the expenses does number bear the character of the allowance for meeting expenses but for performing the duties of the office or employment. This would be so even if the employer has disabled himself from demanding refund of the amount number expended for meeting the expenses incurred or to be incurred in the performance of the duties of an office or employment of profit, and the surplus remaining in the hands of the grantee acquires for the purpose of the Income-tax Act the character of additional remuneration.

issues.text: Whether for a special allowance covering a period longer than the accounting year, the Income-tax Officer must apportion it and exempt only the portion relating to expenses incurred in the year of account?

anchor.surface_text: The expression incurred means for reasons already set out incurred or to be incurred. But that has number bearing on the question whether the unexpended surplus in the hands of the employee is taxable. ... If it appears from a review of the circumstances that a special allowance is made for a period longer than the year of account, or that the period companyered by the grant of a special allowance extends beyond the close of the account year, it would, in our judgment, be the duty of the income-tax Officer to determine the amount allowed in respect of the year of account in which the expenditure has been incurred, and the difference between the amount so determined and the amount actually expended would alone be brought to tax.

arguments.court_reasoning: Only the portion wholly and necessarily incurred in the year of account is exempt; unexpended surplus taxable as income

anchor.surface_text: The clause grants exemption in respect of expenses incurred but on that account an allowance granted to meet expenses to be incurred in future in the performance of the duties of an office or employment of profit is not outside the exemption claimed. In the context in which the expression incurred occurs, it undoubtedly, means incurred or to be incurred.

arguments.claim: purpose for which the allowance is granted is alone not determinative of the claim to exemption under s. 4(3)(vi)

anchor.surface_text: But the purpose for which the allowance is granted, in our judgment, is alone not determinative of the claim to exemption. An allowance though made to a person holding an office or employment of profit intended for appropriation towards expenditure incurred or to be incurred in the discharge of the duties, does not constitute any real income of the grantee.

arguments.claim: surplus remaining after meeting expenses does not bear character of allowance but acquires character of additional remuneration taxable

anchor.surface_text: any surplus remaining in the hands of the grantee after meeting the expenses does not bear the character of the allowance for meeting expenses but for performing the duties of the office or employment. This would be so even if the employer has disabled himself from demanding refund of the amount not expended for meeting the expenses incurred or to be incurred in the performance of the duties of an office or employment of profit, and the surplus remaining in the hands of the grantee acquires for the purpose of the Income-tax Act the character of additional remuneration.

arguments.claim: unable to agree with Bombay HC in Tejaji case that object/purpose of grant determines exemption under s.4(3)(vi)

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree with the decision of the Bombay High Court in Tejaji Farasram Kharawallas case 1  that the object with which the grant is made by the employer determines the claim to exemption under S. 4 3  vi  of the Income-tax Act. The observations made by Chagla, C.J., at p. 267 that what is emphasized in this sub-clause S. 4 3  vi  is the purpose of the grant, the object with which the grant was made.

arguments.claim: do not feel impressed by Allahabad HC in Sharma Company reasoning on unexpended surplus and annual tax frustration

anchor.surface_text: The judgment of the Allahabad High Court in Commissioner of Income-tax, U. P. v. Sharma Company 1  and especially the observations of Pathak, J., on which reliance was placed by counsel, for the Company may also be referred to. ... And we do not feel impressed by the second consideration.

arguments.claim: counsel for Company relies on Pathak J observations in Sharma Company for exemption without actual expenditure proof

court_response_anchor.surface_text: learned Judge in so holding was impressed by two companysiderations that the expression incurred means incurred already, or to be incurred in future a

arguments.court_reasoning: Not impressed; unexpended surplus taxable despite purpose

arguments.claim: duty of ITO to apportion special allowance over period covered and tax difference after actual expenditure in year of account

anchor.surface_text: If it appears from a review of the circumstances that a special allowance is made for a period longer than the year of account, or that the period covered by the grant of a special allowance extends beyond the close of the account year, it would, in our judgment, be the duty of the income-tax Officer to determine the amount allowed in respect of the year of account in which the expenditure has been incurred, and the difference between the amount so determined and the amount actually expended would alone be brought to tax.

arguments.claim: Finance Act 1955 amendment clarifies exemption only to extent actually incurred but principle of apportionment applies

anchor.surface_text: It may be noted that the Parliament has by the Finance Act, 1955, with effect from April 1, 1955, recast cl.  vi  of s. 4 3  of the Income-tax Act, 1922 and has expressly provided that the special allowance granted to meet expenses wholly and necessarily incurred in the performance of the duties of an office or employment of profit to the extent to which such expenses are actually incurred for that purpose, was exempt from tax.

arguments.claim: selling agent under the agreement holds an employment of profit

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt that the selling agent under the agreement with the principals holds an employment for profit. No argument to the contrary was advanced before us.

arguments.claim: Bombay High Court under misapprehension; Tejaji case did not decide the referred question

anchor.surface_text: It appears that in so observing the Court was under some misapprehension, for the question referred by the Tribunal had not been decided in the earlier judgment.

holdings.text: In the context in which the expression 'incurred' occurs, it undoubtedly means incurred or to be incurred.

anchor.surface_text: In the context in which the expression incurred occurs, it undoubtedly, means incurred or to be incurred. To qualify for exemption the allowance must it is clear be granted to meet expenses incurred or to be incurred wholly and necessarily in the performance of the duties of an office or employment of profit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of 'incurred' in s.4(3)(vi) includes future expenses in context of exemption clause.

holdings.text: The purpose for which the allowance is granted is alone not determinative of the claim to exemption.

anchor.surface_text: But the purpose for which the allowance is granted, in our judgment, is alone not determinative of the claim to exemption. An allowance though made to a person holding an office or employment of profit intended for appropriation towards expenditure incurred or to be incurred in the discharge of the duties, does not constitute any real income of the grantee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Allowance qualifies for exemption only to extent meeting expenses wholly necessarily incurred; purpose insufficient alone.

holdings.text: Any surplus remaining in the hands of the grantee after meeting the expenses does not bear the character of the allowance for meeting expenses but acquires the character of additional remuneration taxable under the Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: any surplus remaining in the hands of the grantee after meeting the expenses does not bear the character of the allowance for meeting expenses but for performing the duties of the office or employment. This would be so even if the employer has disabled himself from demanding refund of the amount not expended for meeting the expenses incurred or to be incurred in the performance of the duties of an office or employment of profit, and the surplus remaining in the hands of the grantee acquires for the purpose of the Income-tax Act the character of additional remuneration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unexpended surplus loses exempt character even if non-refundable, becomes additional remuneration.

holdings.text: We are unable to agree with the decision of the Bombay High Court in Tejaji Farasram Kharawalla's case that the object with which the grant is made by the employer determines the claim to exemption under s.4(3)(vi).

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree with the decision of the Bombay High Court in Tejaji Farasram Kharawallas case 1 that the object with which the grant is made by the employer determines the claim to exemption under S. 4 3 vi of the Income-tax Act. The observations made by Chagla, C.J., at p. 267 that what is emphasized in this sub-clause S. 4 3 vi is the purpose of the grant, the object with which the grant was made.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes prior precedent emphasizing purpose over actual necessity of expenses.

holdings.text: If it appears from a review of the circumstances that a special allowance is made for a period longer than the year of account... it would be the duty of the income-tax Officer to determine the amount allowed in respect of the year of account in which the expenditure has been incurred, and the difference between the amount so determined and the amount actually expended would alone be brought to tax.

anchor.surface_text: If it appears from a review of the circumstances that a special allowance is made for a period longer than the year of account, or that the period covered by the grant of a special allowance extends beyond the close of the account year, it would, in our judgment, be the duty of the income-tax Officer to determine the amount allowed in respect of the year of account in which the expenditure has been incurred, and the difference between the amount so determined and the amount actually expended would alone be brought to tax.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Apportionment required for multi-year allowances; only year-specific net amount taxable, rejecting frustration of annual levy argument.

holdings.text: There is no doubt that the selling agent under the agreement with the principals holds an employment for profit.

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt that the selling agent under the agreement with the principals holds an employment for profit. No argument to the contrary was advanced before us. It is unnecessary therefore to consider the elaborate judgment of the High Court on the question whether the selling agent holds an office within the meaning of s. 4 3 vi of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application; no contrary argument; accepts prior findings on agency nature.

holdings.text: That portion of 5 per cent of the selling agency commission received by the assessee company is exempt under s. 4(3)(vi) of the Income-tax Act, 1922, which is wholly and necessarily incurred in the year of account in the performance of the duties of the company as selling agent.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies s.4(3)(vi) interpretation to facts; allows appeal discharging HC full exemption.

precedents.citation: Tejaji Farasram Kharawalla v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay  Mofussil  1

anchor.surface_text: in Tejaji Farasram Kharawalla v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay  Mofussil  1 -which arose out of a proceeding for assessment to tax of the income of the original selling agent under the same agency agreement. It appears that in so observing the Court was under some misapprehension, for the question referred by the Tribunal had number been decided in the earlier judgment. Against the order passed by the High Court recording an answer in the affirmative on the question referred by the Tribunal and against the order dismissing the numberice of motion, the Commissioner appealed to this Court.

precedents.case_name: Tejaji Farasram Kharawalla v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: conclusively determined that assessee held office or employment of profit under s. 4(3)(vi)

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree with the decision of the Bombay High Court in Tejaji Farasram Kharawallas case 1  that the object with which the grant is made by the employer determines the claim to exemption under S. 4 3  vi  of the Income-tax Act. The observations made by Chagla, C.J., at p. 267 that what is emphasized in this sub-clause S. 4 3  vi  is the purpose of the grant, the object with which the grant was made. Once it is established that the grant was for that particular purpose, it is numberlonger necessary for the assessee to prove that in fact he expended that grant for the purpose for which it was given.

precedents.case_name: Tejaji Farasram Kharawalla v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: purpose/object of grant determines exemption under s. 4(3)(vi); no need to prove actual expenditure
precedents.cited_holding: Once it is established that the grant was for that particular purpose, it is no longer necessary for the assessee to prove that in fact he expended that grant for the purpose for which it was given. He may spend more, or he may spend less, but qua that grant which is given for a particular purpose, he is entitled to the exemption

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax, U. P. v. Sharma Company 1

anchor.surface_text: The judgment of the Allahabad High Court in Commissioner of Income-tax, U. P. v. Sharma Company 1  and especially the observations of Pathak, J., on which reliance was placed by companynsel, for the Company may also be referred to. In Sharma Companys case 1  the assessee firm which was the sole selling agent of a companyton mill, received a sum exceeding Rs. 67,000/- from the owners of the mills for the purpose of meeting the expenses in companynection with the management of a retail cloth shop on behalf of the mill and actually spent only Rs. 12,641/-.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, U. P. v. Sharma Company
precedents.cited_proposition: purpose of grant determines exemption under s. 4(3)(vi); no need to prove actual expenditure by recipient; unexpended surplus exempt
precedents.cited_holding: s. 4(3)(vi) requires Income-tax Officer to enquire whether purpose of grant covered by clause, not whether amount actually expended

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is therefore allowed and the answer recorded by the High Court to the supplementary question is discharged, and the following answer to the supplementary question is recorded That portion of 5 per cent of the selling agency companymission received by the assessee companypany is exempt under s. 4  3

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed. High Court's answer to supplementary question discharged. New answer recorded: only portion of 5% selling agency commission wholly and necessarily incurred in year of account for duties as selling agent is exempt under s. 4(3)(vi) of 1922 Act.
directions: Answer recorded by High Court to the supplementary question is discharged.

Following answer to the supplementary question is recorded: That portion of 5 per cent of the selling agency commission received by the assessee company is exempt under s. 4(3) of the Income-tax Act, 1922, which is wholly and necessarily incurred in the year of account in the performance of the duties of the company as selling agent.

anchor.surface_text: In the context in which the expression incurred occurs, it undoubtedly, means incurred or to be incurred. To qualify for exemption the allowance must it is clear be granted to meet expenses incurred or to be incurred wholly and necessarily in the performance of the duties of an office or employment of profit.

The appeal is therefore allowed and the answer recorded by the High Court to the supplementary question is discharged, and the following answer to the supplementary question is recorded That portion of 5 per cent of the selling agency companymission received by the assessee companypany is exempt under s. 4  3

anchor.surface_text: pose for which the allowance is granted, in our judgment, is alone number determinative of the claim to exemption. An a

edges.explanation: Holding states purpose alone is not determinative, directly answering the issue.

anchor.surface_text: But the purpose for which the allowance is granted, in our judgment, is alone not determinative of the claim to exemption. An allowance though made to a person holding an office or employment of profit intended for appropriation towards expenditure incurred or to be incurred in the discharge of the duties, does not constitute any real income of the grantee.

The appeal is therefore allowed and the answer recorded by the High Court to the supplementary question is discharged, and the following answer to the supplementary question is recorded That portion of 5 per cent of the selling agency companymission received by the assessee companypany is exempt under s. 4  3

anchor.surface_text: any surplus remaining in the hands of the grantee after meeting the expenses does not bear the character of the allowance for meeting expenses but for performing the duties of the office or employment. This would be so even if the employer has disabled himself from demanding refund of the amount not expended for meeting the expenses incurred or to be incurred in the performance of the duties of an office or employment of profit, and the surplus remaining in the hands of the grantee acquires for the purpose of the Income-tax Act the character of additional remuneration.

The appeal is therefore allowed and the answer recorded by the High Court to the supplementary question is discharged, and the following answer to the supplementary question is recorded That portion of 5 per cent of the selling agency companymission received by the assessee companypany is exempt under s. 4  3

edges.explanation: Holding directs apportionment for allowances over longer periods, addressing the issue.

anchor.surface_text: If it appears from a review of the circumstances that a special allowance is made for a period longer than the year of account, or that the period covered by the grant of a special allowance extends beyond the close of the account year, it would, in our judgment, be the duty of the income-tax Officer to determine the amount allowed in respect of the year of account in which the expenditure has been incurred, and the difference between the amount so determined and the amount actually expended would alone be brought to tax.

The appeal is therefore allowed and the answer recorded by the High Court to the supplementary question is discharged, and the following answer to the supplementary question is recorded That portion of 5 per cent of the selling agency companymission received by the assessee companypany is exempt under s. 4  3

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt that the selling agent under the agreement with the principals holds an employment for profit. No argument to the contrary was advanced before us. It is unnecessary therefore to consider the elaborate judgment of the High Court on the question whether the selling agent holds an office within the meaning of s. 4 3 vi of the Act.

The appeal is therefore allowed and the answer recorded by the High Court to the supplementary question is discharged, and the following answer to the supplementary question is recorded That portion of 5 per cent of the selling agency companymission received by the assessee companypany is exempt under s. 4  3
